climbs.name: Barracuda
climbs.fa: bolted by Chris Barnes, Vernon Phinney, and Mike Engle, July 2017

content.description: This is the easiest way to gain the large ledge below The Wall.  Start right of Stairway to Heaven on featured rock.  Move up and then right to a shallow right facing corner.  Move left and make the same mantel and step across as Stairway to Heaven.  Follow easy climbing to the ledge below The Wall.  Shares last 3 bolts with Stairway to Heaven.
content.protection: 7 bolts, Chain anchors on the ledge below The Wall.  Single rappel on a 60 meter rope to descend.
content.location:
Start 10 feet right of Stairway to Heaven.

See the

beta picture for relative location.

climbs.name: Us and Them
climbs.fa: FA:  Mike Engle and Linda Engle, July 2017  bolted by Chris Barnes, Vernon Phinney, and Mike Engle, July 2017

content.description:
This is one of 6 routes that is accessed from the broad ledge below a broad steep face called "The Wall". Use one of 4 approach pitch options (Don't Bring Me Down, I Turn to Stone, Stairway to Heaven, or Barracuda) to gain chain anchors on a comfortable ledge.

Us and Them starts just right of the chain anchors and climb straight up continuous, steep thin chert for 100 feet right up the middle of the face. The chert is strong but brittle, especially when wet. Be careful to place feet on holds and don't kick them. The holds are half pad crimps to full on jugs. Thin and thoughtful climbing starts immediately off the ledge and doesn't let up until you clip the anchors.
content.protection: 12 bolts, chain anchors.  Single rappel on a 60 meter rope gets you back to the ledge.  Another single rappel on a 60 meter rope gets you back to the ground.
content.location:
Middle route on "The Wall".

See the

beta picture for relative location.

content.description:
Steep climbing on solid grey limestone.  Make a series of interesting and challenging moves between grooves and pockets.  After 5 or 6 bolts, pull onto the narrow ledge shared with Stairway to Heaven.  Follow easy ground and a couple more bolts to the large grassy ledge below The Wall.

This is one of 4 approach options for getting to the climbs on The Wall.
content.protection: 7 or 8 bolts.  Chain anchors on the ledge below The Wall.  Single rappel on a 60 meter rope to descend.
content.location:
10 feet right of Don't Bring Me Down and 10 feet left of Stairway to Heaven.

See the

beta picture for relative location.

climbs.name: Total Eclipse
climbs.fa: Chris Barnes Aug 2017, bolted by Chris Barnes, Vernon Phinney,,& Mike Engle

content.description:
The far right wall of Psychedelic Rock has a very prominent steep right facing corner with a crack. Start on a steep face and traverse left until you can establish a stem in the corner.  Follow the corner/crack until the crack ends (about 80 feet). Face climb between discontinuous cracks for another 40 feet to the anchors just below the crest of the fin.

Long and sustained climb.

First climbed on the afternoon of the 2017 Total Eclipse.
content.protection:
17 bolts.  Chain anchors, 2 rope rappel to the ground is the recommended descent.

Note:  it is possible to do a short rappel to the top of Thriller.  From those sport anchors it is another rap to the ground on a single 60 meter rope.

Caution needed when clipping into sport anchors while on rappel.  The sport anchor uses two 1/2 X 5" bolts. One bolt is used with chain, quick link, & steel carabiner and the second bolt is used with an open cold shut.  Use an open cold shut only when weighted from below. Always use redundant tie in points at rap stations.
content.location:
From the high point of the trail at the base of Psychedelic Rock, continue down 20 feet right before the trail climbs up again.  Looking up and right there is a prominent arch/cave.  The left side of Psychedelic Rock is a steep wall with a prominent overhang and a sweeping right facing corner/dihedral/crack system.  Scramble up to a small staging area below the wall.

Total Eclipse is the leftmost route up the steep dihedral.

climbs.name: Time
climbs.fa: Mike Engle, Chris Barnes, & Vernon Phinney; Aug 2018

content.description:
This is one of 6 routes that is accessed from the broad ledge below a broad steep face called "The Wall". Use one of 4 approach pitch options (Don't Bring Me Down, I Turn to Stone, Stairway to Heaven, or Barracuda) to gain chain anchors on a comfortable ledge.

Time starts 10 feet to right of the chain anchors on the comfortable ledge.  Move up the left side of a small alcove just off the ledge.  Continue on thin chert and aim for the larger alcove up and left.  Climb to the apex of the alcove and pull onto the chert face above.  The climbing eases up on huge chert.  Continue to the anchors of Another Brick in the Wall.
content.protection: 12 or 13 bolts.  Sport anchor, lower back to the ledge with a 60 meter rope.
content.location: Start 10 feet left of the chain anchors on ledge at the base of 'The Wall'.

climbs.name: Thriller
climbs.fa: Mike & Linda Engle Aug 2017  bolted by Mike Engle and Chris Barnes

content.description:
On the rightmost face of Psychedelic Rock, there is an attractive grey face next to an orange streak.

Face climb on chert until you get a mono. Begin moving up on increasingly larger pockets into yellow/brown rock and large overhang.  Pull the overhang on mostly big holds and move into large alcove.  The the top of the alcove traverse left a few feet over a shallow right facing corner.  Continue up to a stance and work a vertical edge for a few more moves to the anchors.
content.protection: 12 bolts. Sport anchor. Single 60 meter rope will get you back to the ground.
content.location:
From the high point of the trail at the base of Psychedelic Rock, continue 20 feet down before the trail climbs up again.  Looking up and right there is a prominent arch/cave.  The left side of Psychedelic Rock is a steep wall with a prominent overhang and a sweeping right facing corner/dihedral/crack system.  Scramble up to a small staging area below the wall.

Thriller is the center route that starts on a thin steep slab and continues to a prominent crack through overhanging rock.

content.description:
Move up solid grey limestone on good holds.  When the good holds run out move up one more bolt on thin crimps and thin feet until you can get a right hand out around the edge of a shallow right facing corner.  Continue up the face working the left hand up the face and the right hand on the edge.  Make a mantle onto narrow ledge and do an awkward step left on slopper footholds and no hands.  Continue on easy ground to gain the large ledge below the headwall - The Wall.

This is one of 4 approach options for getting to the climbs on The Wall.
content.protection: 7 or 8 bolts.  Chain anchors on the ledge below The Wall.  Single rappel on a 60 meter rope to descend.
content.location:
10 feet right of Turn to Stone.

See the

beta picture for relative location.

climbs.name: Run Like Hell
climbs.fa: bolted by Chris Barnes, Vernon Phinney, and Mike Engle, July 2017

content.description:
This is one of 6 routes that is accessed from the broad ledge below a broad steep face called "The Wall". Use one of 4 approach pitch options (Don't Bring Me Down, I Turn to Stone, Stairway to Heaven, or Barracuda) to gain chain anchors on a comfortable ledge.

Run Like Hell starts 15 feet left of the chain anchors and climbs continuous, steep thin chert for 100 feet.  Work up on thin chert until you are close to the right edge of a huge alcove in the rock. Work your right hand and foot on the edge for a couple bolts until pulling fully back onto the chert face. Continuous climbing on chert continues to the anchor.
content.protection: 12 bolts, chain anchors.  Single rappel on a 60 meter rope gets you back to the ledge.  Another single rappel on a 60 meter rope gets you back to the ground.
content.location:
The climb starts 15 feet right of the chain anchors at the base of 'The Wall'.

See the

beta picture for relative location.

climbs.name: Money
climbs.fa: Chris Barnes, Mike Engle & Vernon Phinney, Aug 2018

content.description: Climb up featured, sculpted limestone with distinctive right diagonalling fissures. Work straight up across the fissures to a thin move.  Continue on slightly easier climbing to the anchors.
content.protection: 10 or 12 bolts, sport anchors.  Single 60 meter rope to lower.
content.location: Follow the trail right along the base of Psychedelic Rock and the climb is on right side of this broad wall at the base and starts just before the trail descends.

content.description: Cool features on this climb with a cruxy middle section. Climb a short wall to a stance below a left trending left facing corner. Climb up and pull over the overlap (right over the shallow corner).  Continue up to the anchors just below a ledge.
content.location:
Starts right of Highway to Hell.

See the

beta picture for relative location.

content.description: Long route that needs traffic to clean up. Fun! Cool pockets, flakes, and runnels.
content.location:
Right of Cajun Hot Stick. Just left of Highway to Hell.

See the

beta picture for relative location.

climbs.name: Jumping Jack Flash
climbs.fa: Mike Engle and Linda Engle Sept 2017

content.description: This is the right most route on Psychedelic Rock.  Move quickly left through 2 bolts on marginal rock to gain the good rock on the obvious arete. Face climb up and left to a stance below a grey, very featured and sharp overhang.  Negotiate the overhang to a stance below a shallow right facing corner.  Make a few easier moves past a couple more bolts to the anchors.
content.protection: 7 bolts, sport anchors.  Descend with a single 60 meter rope.
content.location: On the far right side of Psychedelic Rock is an obvious large shallow cave.  From the platform, move up and left past some marginal rock in the cave.  There is a bolt and hanger for the belayer so they won't be pulled off the platform in case of a fall.

climbs.name: Highway to Hell
climbs.fa: Mike Engle, Jordan Allen, & Chris Olsen July 2017

content.description: Just right of a bush climb past a bolt to a narrow ledge.  Work up and right towards a large chert knob.  Once standing on the knob, make a couple moves laterally to the right and gain a stance below a large chert patch just out of reach.  Make  a thin cranky move (or two) to gain the chert. Campus up the chert on decent hand holds and terrible feet until you gain some stabilizing jugs.  Easy climbing past a couple more bolts leads to the anchors.
content.protection: 8 bolts, sport anchors.  Single 60 meter rope and one rappel to descend.
content.location:
Starts right of large bush growing out of the base of the cliff and left of the Bingham route Matchhead.

See the

beta picture for relative location.

climbs.name: The Flaming (c)Lips
climbs.fa: Mike Engle, Chris Barnes, & Vernon Phinney; Aug 2018

content.description: This is a fun, but very short climb on excellent featured rock.  Unfortunately the route ends when the featured rock ends.  Climb up a weakness with a discontinuous crack to a small ledge.  Continue on enjoyable rock for another 20 feet to stnace where the rock blanks out to a thin desperate slab.  Clip the sport anchors and lower.
content.location: On the left side of Psychedelic Rock, uphill about 20 feet from where the approach trail intersects with a large staging area at the base of the crag.

climbs.name: Empty Spaces
climbs.fa: Chris Barnes, Mike Engle & Vernon Phinney, Aug 2018

content.description:
This is one of 6 routes that is accessed from the broad ledge below a broad steep face called "The Wall". Use one of 4 approach pitch options (Don't Bring Me Down, I Turn to Stone, Stairway to Heaven, or Barracuda) to gain chain anchors on a comfortable ledge.

Empty Spaces has a couple ways to begin the climb.  From the anchors on the broad ledge below 'The Wall', move left and stem up an easy corner past a couple trees clipping a couple bolts along the way.  From the big dead spruce tree, pull onto the wall and follow good chert up to a small ledge about 1/2 way up, continue on amazing, easy huge chert to a final headwall.  Work up a couple of runnels with occasional baseball sized chert knobs to the anchors.

Alternatively, it's possible to move the belay from the chain anchors on the broad ledge below to 'The Wall' up the easy stemming corner past the trees to another set of chain anchors just past the dead spruce and lead the climb from there.
content.protection: 12 - 13 bolts.  Sport anchors for lowering.  Pay attention to the descent on this route.  With a 60 meter rope lower to the chain anchors at the top of the stemming corner by the big dead spruce.  With a 70 meter rope it's possible to lower back to the chain anchors on the broad ledge at the base of "The Wall'.  With either set of chain anchors it is another rappel back to the ground with a 60 meter rope.
content.location: This is the left most route that is accessed from the chain anchors on the broad ledge below 'The Wall'.

climbs.name: Don't Bring Me Down
climbs.fa: Mike Engle and Chris Barnes, July 2017

content.description:
Start below a couple shallow depressions in the wall.   Move straight up into the first depression and move up and slightly left to the second depression.  Make a tough move right then up to a gaston in a featured water groove.  Struggle for a couple moves through the water groove to gain a small ledge.  Continue up past another bolt to gain a large ledge and anchors below a large featured chert wall - "The Wall".

This is one of four options as an approach pitch to the climbs on The Wall.
content.protection: 7 or 8 bolts.  Chain anchors on the ledge below The Wall.  Single rappel with a 60 meter rope to descend.
content.location:
Starts 10 feet right of the Bingham route Matchhead.

See the

beta picture for relative location.

content.description:
Follow the left side of the prominent grey pillar to the right of "The Wall" and just right of the huge alcove.

This is one of 6 routes that is accessed from the broad ledge below a broad steep face called "The Wall". Use one of 4 approach pitch options (Don't Bring Me Down, I Turn to Stone, Stairway to Heaven, or Barracuda) to gain chain anchors on a comfortable ledge.

Use one of several approach pitch options to get to the comfortable ledge below "The Wall". Move the belay to the anchors on the far right side of the ledge. Move right to gain the face of the pillar. Work up the face sometimes working a hand or more on the left edge of the pillar. Continue up to a steep bulge with a short finger crack. Continue up on vertical chert to the anchors.
content.protection: 10 bolts and sport anchors. Single 60 meter rope gets you back to the ledge.  Second rap gets you back to the ground.
content.location: Starting on the big ledge below "The Wall", Comfortably Numb is the route just Right of Run Like Hell.

content.description: Nice Climbing down low to an obvious crux. 10+ slab climbing for sure.
content.protection: 7 bolts to chains. Be careful traversing to the right to the anchors. They are a ways to the right but the climbing backs off.
content.location:
Leftmost route on Psychedelic Rock.Starts just to the right of a water groove with large burned log leaning up against it.

See the

beta picture for relative location.

climbs.name: Another Brick in the Wall
climbs.fa: Mike Engle and Jordan Allen, July 2017; bolted by Chris Barnes, Vernon Phinney, & Mike Engle, July 2017

content.description:
This is one of 6 routes that is accessed from the broad ledge below a broad steep face called "The Wall". Use one of 4 approach pitch options (Don't Bring Me Down, I Turn to Stone, Stairway to Heaven, or Barracuda) to gain chain anchors on a comfortable ledge.

Another Brick in the Wall starts just left of the chain anchors and climb continuous, steep thin chert staying right of an obvious alcove about half way up the 100 foot wall. The chert is strong but brittle, especially when wet.  Be careful to place feet on holds and don't kick them. The holds are half pad crimps to full on jugs. This is another thin, technical climb that is continuously engaging. Just before the second to last bolt you can make a move left and grab a good rail to ease the tension.
content.protection: 13 bolts, chain anchors.  Single rappel on a 60 meter rope gets you back to the ledge.  Another single rappel on a 60 meter rope gets you back to the ground.
content.location:
The route starts 5 feet to the left of the chain anchors at the base of 'The Wall'.

See the

beta picture for relative location.
